269. Edwards, (Mrs. George)
WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Geo. Edwards
Address Lambourn, Sask.
Birthplace London, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? Lambourn District
Where had you been living before that? London, England
For how many people did you prepare meals? Four
How far was it to your nearest store? Three miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Each day if necessary
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, tea, sugar, syrup, salt, soda, baking powder, raisins, beans, dried peaches, coffee, beer, tobacco, coal and candles

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Imperial Household and Fine Rose
In what quantities did you buy it? 98 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.95
How much did you use Graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? 9 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75 cents
What other grain products did you use? None
Cornmeal? No
Whole wheat? No
Farina? No
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
1909. Edwards, Mrs. Geo.
Lashburn.

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Centre, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon.

Name: Mrs. Geo. Edwards
Address: Barry Lake

1. PERIOD OF RESIDENCE
   What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? 1910
   Where did you come from before that? Barry Lake, England
   How many people did you bring with you? 2
   How far was it to your nearest store? 5 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Each day

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   In what quantities did you buy flour? 98 pounds
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.94
   How much did you use cracked flour? None
   What kind of flour did you buy? Hard Red
   Was flour milled locally? No
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75¢
   Did you grind your own wheat for grinding? No
   Did you grind your own corn? No
   Did you raise your own grain? No
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 and 20 lb. bags.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 85 cents.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rockingham.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.

At what price? 70 cents.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

By milking cows.

Butter? By churning eggs? From chickens.

What was the price of butter? 10-25 cts.

Did you keep eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? By raising beef, chickens, and wild fowl.

How did you get fresh meat? By butchering own animals.

How often did you get fresh meat? Fresh by freezing in winter.

How did you preserve meat? Canned beef and pork, packed in lard.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Prairie chickens, ducks, rabbits.

For how long? About 3 months in the fall.

What part did fish play in the family diet? None.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned.

Kinds? Salmon, sardines, herring.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early days?

How did you get fresh meat? By killing animals.

How often did you eat fresh meat? Twice a week.

How did you store meat? In the refrigerator.

Was there a "meat river" in your neighborhood? No

If so what year was it organized? 1910

Did you use canned meat? Yes

For how long? About 3 months on the farm

What part did fish play in the family diet? None

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned

Kind of fish? Salmon, haddock, herring
